item.title: Word of the Day: voracious
item.description: This word has appeared in 103 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
item.dc:creator: The Learning Network

item.title: Un tribunal permite temporalmente que el ICE use gas pimienta
item.description: El Octavo Circuito accedió a la petición del gobierno de Trump de bloquear, por el momento, el mandato judicial de un tribunal inferior que limitaba la forma en que los agentes federales interactúan con los manifestantes en Minnesota.
item.dc:creator: Mitch Smith

media:content.media:description: Agentes federales se enfrentaron a manifestantes tras el asesinato de Renee Good en Mineápolis a principios de mes.

item.title: NATO as We Know It Is Coming to an End, and That’s OK
item.description: Europe has a chance to step out of America’s shadow.
item.dc:creator: Rajan Menon

media:content.media:credit: Illustration by Sam Whitney/The New York Times

item.title: Latin Americans Love the Right. Can You Blame Them?
item.description: The right is ascendant in Latin America. How long will it last?
item.dc:creator: Michael Reid

item.title: Trump Rescinds Canada’s Invitation to Join His ‘Board of Peace’
item.description: The president appeared to be lashing out in response to stark, high-profile remarks by Prime Minister Mark Carney of Canada that rejected Mr. Trump’s efforts to dismantle the international order.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron and Matina Stevis-Gridneff

item.title: No Beer for You: How British Pubs Fought a Tax Increase
item.description: More than 1,400 pubs declared a ban on Labour lawmakers in response to a plan to raise business rates significantly. The move got attention, and results.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle and Andrew Testa

media:content.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Landlord Andy Lennox at his pub, The Old Thatch, earlier this month.

item.title: That ‘Crazy’ Compliment He Never Forgot
item.description: At a birthday party two years ago, Sarah Gall boldly told Holden Rosen Grupp that he was cute and to call her if he was ever single. Several months later, he did just that.
item.dc:creator: Valeriya Safronova

item.title: Corrections: Jan. 23, 2026
item.description: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Jan. 23, 2026.

item.title: A College Film Project Turned Into a Life Together
item.description: Casey DelBasso and Christopher Kelley met on the first day of college and instantly clicked, but it was almost three years before they became a couple.
item.dc:creator: Donna Kim

item.title: The ‘Invisible Strings’ That Brought Them Together
item.description: Samantha Podell and Robert Mitchell met through a dating app nearly five years ago and soon discovered they had a lot in common.
item.dc:creator: Shivani Vora

item.title: Love Found Its Pace in a New York Walking Group
item.description: Margaret Victor and Chuck Barraza met through Shorewalkers, an environmental walking group. On their first date, Ms. Victor was “really thrown” to learn that he was 16 years her senior.
item.dc:creator: Tammy LaGorce

item.title: The Kiss That Stopped Traffic
item.description: If you choose to live your life on the road, you may end up having the best kiss of your life in the middle of the street.
item.dc:creator: Marya Hornbacher

item.title: Quote of the Day: Sharp Words Split Alliance
item.description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, January 23, 2025.

item.title: D.H.S. Cited Foreign Students’ Writings and Protests Before Their Arrests
item.description: Documents unsealed by a federal judge on Thursday include dossiers that investigators prepared on pro-Palestinian student activists before they were targeted for deportation.
item.dc:creator: Zach Montague

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio approved the revocation of visas for five international students last year.

item.title: National Park Service Dismantles Slavery Exhibit in Philadelphia
item.description: The exhibit memorialized nine people enslaved by George Washington. The Park Service said it was being removed in accordance with a directive from President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Ahn

media:content.media:description: An outdoor exhibit on slavery at Independence National Historical Park in Philadelphia in October. The National Park Service has taken down the exhibit.

item.title: White House Posts Altered Photo Showing Arrested Minnesota Protester Crying
item.description: The New York Times ran the image posted by Kristi Noem, the homeland security secretary, as well as the one posted by the White House through an A.I. detection system. It concluded that the White House’s version showed signs of manipulation.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany Hsu, Alan Feuer and Stuart A. Thompson

media:content.media:description: Nekima Levy Armstrong after speaking at an anti-ICE rally in St. Paul, Minn., on Monday. The Justice Department said on Thursday morning that it had taken her into custody, accusing her of helping to interrupt a church service in St. Paul.

item.title: Will I Have to Download a New TikTok App? And Other Big Questions About The Deal.
item.description: The popular short form video app has a new corporate structure in the United States, which could result in some changes for the 200 million Americans who use TikTok.
item.dc:creator: Emmett Lindner

media:content.media:credit: José A. Alvarado Jr. for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: It is unclear how much, if anything, will change for TikTok’s 200 million American users.

item.title: NYT Crossword Answers for Jan. 23, 2026
item.description: Joyce Keller opens our solving weekend.
item.dc:creator: Sam Corbin

media:content.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Solving a Friday puzzle doesn’t have to be a pipe dream! Read Wordplay for hints.

item.title: ‘The Pitt’ Season 2 Episode 3 Recap: Expect the Unexpected
item.description: The doctors are seeing a lot of rare cases on this Fourth of July. Not even the fireworks-related injuries have been straightforward.
item.dc:creator: Sean T. Collins

media:content.media:description: When Dr. Al-Hashimi (Sepideh Moafi) isn’t butting heads with Dr. Robby, she has excellent bedside manner.

item.title: Here’s Who Just Bought TikTok
item.description: Several big companies and investment firms are part of the new American TikTok. Many have ties to one another and President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Emmett Lindner

media:content.media:credit: Andres Kudacki for The New York Times

item.title: Applications Open for the 2026 New York Portfolio Review
item.description: Apply now for this free event for photographers.
item.dc:creator: James Estrin

item.title: Man Accused in $100 Million Jewel Heist Is Deported, Thwarting Trial
item.description: The move comes as ICE seeks to deport more people charged with crimes, sometimes before their cases are resolved.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan

media:content.media:description: In a photo released by the F.B.I., a jewelry showcase displays some of the items that were taken during the July 11, 2022, jewelry heist in California.

item.title: Face to Face With Jacques-Louis David, History’s Most Dangerous Painter
item.description: Jacques-Louis David, artist and politician of the French Revolution, has beguiled our critic Jason Farago for years — and scared him, too. Let him show you why.
item.dc:creator: Jason Farago

item.title: F.A.A. Says Helicopter Restrictions Imposed After D.C. Crash Will Stay
item.description: The agency said that expanding the restrictions and making them permanent were urgent steps for avoiding another crash.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian

media:content.media:description: The new rule for Ronald Reagan National Airport sets strict limits on what “essential operations” could be excepted from the airspace restrictions.

item.title: ByteDance vende la mayor parte de TikTok en EE. UU. para evitar una sanción
item.description: La compañía informó que cedió el control mayoritario de su operación estadounidense para asegurar la continuidad de la plataforma en el país.
item.dc:creator: David McCabe and Emmett Lindner

item.title: Dallas County Exonerates Black Man Who Was Executed in 1956
item.description: An all-white jury convicted Tommy Lee Walker of rape and murder, relying on inadmissible evidence and a coerced confession that he immediately recanted, county officials said.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor

item.title: Jack Smith Defends His Trump Indictments During House Hearing
item.description: Jack Smith, the special prosecutor who twice indicted Donald J. Trump, defended his investigation in a tense and long-awaited appearance before a House committee on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: Jorge Mitssunaga

media:content.media:description: Jack Smith, the special prosecutor who twice indicted Donald J. Trump, at the Capitol on Thursday.

item.title: ICE Demands More Access to Minnesota Inmates. But It’s Complicated.
item.description: The Trump administration said it would ease its immigration operation in Minnesota in exchange for broader access to inmates. Local leaders say they already cooperate significantly.
item.dc:creator: Ernesto Londoño

media:content.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Under Minnesota law, the state’s Department of Corrections must notify U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement officials when an immigrant convicted of a felony is set to be released.

item.title: Driving in Winter? Follow These Expert Tips to Arrive Safely.
item.description: A storm is expected to bring hazardous driving conditions to much of the United States this weekend. Stay home if you can, but those who must travel should take it slow.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra E. Petri and Christine Hauser

media:content.media:description: Drivers navigating a snowy highway in Atlanta in January 2025.

item.title: Nazis, Soviets and Trump: America’s Fixation With Greenland
item.description: The idea that Greenland is essential to the United States has returned with a vengeance in the Trump era.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:description: A Greenlander with his dog sled looking at the Americans’ Thule Air Base in northern Greenland in 1966.

item.title: TikTok Strikes Deal to Create New U.S. Entity and Loosen App’s Ties to China
item.description: The Chinese parent company of the popular video app said a group of non-Chinese investors would create an American TikTok to avoid a federal ban.
item.dc:creator: David McCabe and Emmett Lindner

item.title: Un posible acuerdo sobre Groenlandia abarcaría bases militares soberanas para EE. UU. y prohibiciones para Rusia y China
item.description: Los negociadores han debatido propuestas para detener la influencia rusa y china en el Ártico y transferir la soberanía de áreas de Groenlandia a Estados Unidos, idea a la que se opone Dinamarca.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley, Lara Jakes and Adam Goldman

item.title: Barron Trump llamó a la policía británica al ver que golpeaban a una mujer en una videollamada
item.description: Durante un juicio celebrado esta semana, salió a la luz una llamada de emergencia realizada por el hijo menor del presidente Trump a la policía de Londres el año pasado.
item.dc:creator: Lizzie Dearden and Stephen Castle

media:content.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang para The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Barron Trump en el desfile inaugural del presidente Trump en Washington, DC, en enero del año pasado, días después de su llamada telefónica a la policía de Londres.

item.title: Big Insurers Try to Shift Blame for High Health Costs to Hospitals and Drug Makers
item.description: At two congressional hearings, lawmakers slammed executives of major companies, saying they were failing to rein in the cost of medical care for consumers.
item.dc:creator: Reed Abelson
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
Blue Cross and Blue Shield Assn

media:content.media:description: Stephen Hemsley, chief executive of UnitedHealth Group, left, defended insurers’ practices, along with other companies’ executives, during congressional hearings on Thursday.

item.title: U.S. Formally Withdraws From World Health Organization
item.description: Global health experts worry that a lack of international coordination will lead to death and disaster.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

media:content.media:description: The World Health Organization’s headquarters in Geneva. The Trump administration said that all U.S. government funding to the organization had been terminated.

item.title: New U.S. Rule Aims to Speed Up Mining of the Seafloor
item.description: The Metals Company, a prominent seabed-mining company, applauded the change and filed a new application more than doubling the area it hopes to mine.
item.dc:creator: Sachi Kitajima Mulkey

media:content.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A ship chartered by the Metals Company to explore the viability of mining the seabed in the Pacific in 2021.

item.title: According to Vance, ICE Officers No Longer Have ‘Absolute Immunity’
item.description: Vice President JD Vance appeared to backtrack a previous statement that ICE agents were “protected by absolute immunity” during a press conference on Thursday, after meeting with immigration agents in Minneapolis.
item.dc:creator: Jamie Leventhal

item.title: Mark Carney Says Firmly That ‘Canada Doesn’t Live Because of the United States’
item.description: The Canadian prime minister spoke after returning from the World Economic Forum where he urged middle powers to team up in resisting President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen

media:content.media:description: Prime Minister Mark Carney of Canada at a news conference in Quebec City on Thursday.

item.title: Trump Could Begin Flying on Plane Donated by Qatar by Summer
item.description: It remains unclear whether the aircraft would get the full Air Force One security upgrades, which industry experts said could take up to two years to complete.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager and Eric Schmitt

media:content.media:description: President Trump had to swap to a smaller plane used as Air Force One on Tuesday night, as he was heading to Switzerland, after an electrical issue with the larger aircraft.

item.title: European Leaders Scramble to Find a Path Forward With Trump
item.description: Also, Jack Smith defended his decision to prosecute Trump. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen

item.title: RFK Jr. Plan to Test a Vaccine in West African Babies Is Blocked
item.description: A planned U.S.-funded study of a hepatitis B vaccine drew widespread condemnation from researchers. Now the host country says it cannot proceed.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen and Christina Jewett
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

media:content.media:description: Each year thousands of babies born in Guinea-Bissau, one of the world’s least developed countries, are exposed to hepatitis B, a virus that can cause severe liver damage and cancer.

item.title: No, Trees Don’t Explode When It Gets Cold, but They Do Go Pop
item.description: While the weight of freezing rain, ice and snow can damage branches, there is another kind of injury that comes with the extreme cold, experts say.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan

media:content.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Heavy snow in Prospect Park, in Brooklyn, after a storm in 2024. Much of the United States is bracing for extremely cold conditions this weekend.

item.title: House Rejects Measure to Bar Military Force in Venezuela
item.description: In a tie vote, the House defeated an effort to prohibit the president from using the U.S. military in Venezuela weeks after the raid he ordered that captured the country’s leader.
item.dc:creator: Robert Jimison
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:description: Representative Jim McGovern, Democrat of Massachusetts, at the Capitol on Wednesday. Mr. McGovern, the top Democrat on the Rules Committee, led the effort to bar military force in Venezuela.

item.title: Energy Dept. Says It Is Canceling $30 Billion in Clean Energy Loans
item.description: Many of the cancellations had been known for months, but the announcement underscored the drastic change in the energy landscape under President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer

media:content.media:credit: Callaghan O'Hare for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The Energy Department canceled a partial loan guarantee to Sunnova Energy, a residential solar panel installer that was experimenting with a novel way to link home solar and battery systems.

item.title: James Bernard, a Founding Editor of a Hip-Hop ‘Bible,’ Dies at 58
item.description: One of the most influential voices of the seminal magazine The Source, he chronicled rap’s rise and its explosion into the cultural mainstream.
item.dc:creator: Alex Williams

item.title: Agentes federales detienen a un niño de 5 años en Mineápolis
item.description: Una foto mostraba al niño siendo retenido junto a un vehículo mientras detenían a su padre. El distrito escolar y el gobierno federal han dado versiones contradictorias de lo sucedido.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs

media:content.media:description: Los agentes de migración han estado rodeando las escuelas de Columbia Heights, Minnesota, y siguiendo los autobuses escolares, según la superintendente de la escuela, Zena Stenvik.

item.title: Sense of Relief Spreads Among European Leaders Over De-Escalation of Greenland Crisis
item.description: Some European leaders on Thursday welcomed President Trump’s announcement calling off tariffs on Europe over Greenland, and expressed optimism that it would eventually result in a victory for Arctic security and NATO unity.
item.dc:creator: McKinnon de Kuyper

item.title: Trump to Expand ‘Mexico City’ Abortion Rule to Include D.E.I. and Gender
item.description: The policy has traditionally been aimed at keeping organizations that receive U.S. tax dollars from performing or promoting abortion as a method of family planning.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.category: Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump both reinstated and expanded the “Mexico City policy” in January 2017. His administration is set to broaden the policy again.

item.title: Alfred McLaren, 93, Dies; Submariner Led Secret Cold War Missions
item.description: He participated in the first baseball game at the North Pole. Later, he became an expert in the impact of climate change on Arctic ice sheets.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen

item.title: House Passes Spending Package Over Democratic Revolt on ICE
item.description: Approval of the package, which would fund a wide swath of government agencies, brings Congress closer to meeting a Jan. 30 funding deadline.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson

media:content.media:description: Federal agents in Minneapolis this month, the week after an ICE agent fatally shot Renee Good. Democrats in the House had said they would not vote for legislation that provided funding for ICE, at least not without major changes.
